body: Other solutions to the sig-check is probably make the package to be exposed to friends only. I'd avoid that. @matthiasblaesing  and/or @JaroslavTulach may have other options as well.

@matthiasblaesing well, sigtest does not tell the truth in this case because nothing has changed at the three reported methods. But they have in common that the methods are `public` or `protected` and return a type that is (package) `private`. And they are all in package `com.formdev.flatlaf.ui`, which was not exported before.

> Spotbugs (the successor of FindBugs) no longer [recommends those annotations](https://spotbugs.readthedocs.io/en/stable/migration.html). As such it may not be the right time to add such dormant project to the NetBeans Platform.

If only all was so simple. I did some experiments, and seems SpotBugs still requires the nullness annotations to be meta-annotated using the JSR305 annotations. (Otherwise it simply ignores the annotations.) So, if we remove the meta-annotations, SpotBugs won't work on NetBeans classfiles (not a big deal for me, btw, but I suspect someone would like that to work).

At the same time, I think it makes sense to have @NonNull, etc. annotations, and I agree with Jaroslav that adding jsr305 into the API of the platform does not sound very appealing.

Not sure what is the best way out of this - will try to think about that. In the worst case, we can drop (either manually or at build time) the javax.annotation meta-annotation from our annotations, and accept SpotBugs won't work on NetBeans classfiles.

Hmm, I've increased the Major Release version on the FlatLaf library, but sigtest still fails with the same errors as before...

~~~
RETURN TYPE FOR FlatFileChooserUI::createDirectoryComboBoxRenderer
   CHANGED FROM javax.swing.plaf.metal.MetalFileChooserUI$DirectoryComboBoxRenderer
   TO javax.swing.DefaultListCellRenderer

Hidden return type (can't convert) : com.formdev.flatlaf.ui.FlatScrollPaneUI$Handler
   in method public com.formdev.flatlaf.ui.FlatScrollPaneUI$Handler
   com.formdev.flatlaf.ui.FlatScrollPaneUI.getHandler()

Hidden return type (can't convert) : com.formdev.flatlaf.ui.FlatSpinnerUI$Handler
   in method public com.formdev.flatlaf.ui.FlatSpinnerUI$Handler
   com.formdev.flatlaf.ui.FlatSpinnerUI.getHandler()
~~~

I can fix the two issues with `getHandler()` in a new FlatLaf release, because these methods should be private.

The first error is tricky, because `FlatFileChooserUI` does not have a method `createDirectoryComboBoxRenderer`. This method is in the super class `MetalFileChooserUI` and returns private type `DirectoryComboBoxRenderer` (which extends `DefaultListCellRenderer`).

Seems that sigtest has problems with public or protected methods that return (package) private types.

Is this a known issue?
@jtulach @emilianbold

> Seems that sigtest has problems with public or protected methods that return (package) private types.

It is not sigtest that has a problem. The library exposing such methods has a problem!

Why should an API expose a method that returns package private type? What the callers are going to do with it? How will the Javadoc look like? Having such methods just doesn't make any sense when designing Java APIs.

Of course, the problem is when a 3rd party library which hasn't really paid much attention to its API is then re-exported by NetBeans module and becomes subject to signature testing. There are three possible solutions I can think of:
- disable the signature testing
- fix the library
- improve [sigtest](https://github.com/jtulach/netbeans-apitest) to have an option that would allow the above practice

As an author of [Practical API Design](http://apidesign.org) I am in favor of fixing the library, but I understand that it may be more practical to choose one of the other solutions.

True. Ignore this point.

One more thing. What are the priorities?

I mean what happens, when I add a textmate grammar to a language that already exists? What will win? For the usecase, maybe my grammar is more up to date than the one, coded inside the IDE? For example no one updates the kotlin grammar for years and after 1 or 2 years I decide to add a new one via textmate.

Are there any conflicts or will the textmate then just ignored? Maybe a checkbox would be great to say: please use mine grammar over the default one(?). Just an idea.

@JaroslavTulach
Full agree that that it is a problem in the library to expose such methods and I will fix the two `getHandler()` methods in my library, which are public through an oversight.

But the third problem is in Java 8 class `MetalFileChooserUI`, which I can not fix.
My library simply contains a public class `FlatFileChooserUI` that extends `MetalFileChooserUI`.
`FlatFileChooserUI` must be public because it is loaded by Swing via reflection.

The issue in `MetalFileChooserUI` has been fixed in Java 9: [JDK-8167176](https://bugs.java.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=8167176)
https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/commit/bc442826a9d2ee64ef237c89696b616a0ea7dea0#diff-51ee8b27454e4164799775a61250edee

So, I think I'll rework this PR in a way that it is not necessary to export the package `com.formdev.flatlaf.ui`, which contains the class that extends `MetalFileChooserUI`.

I think it is good to go but wouldn't it be better to load he data from the server instead of hardcoded it into it? Everytime they change smth and I think it changes a lot, we need to update the stuff. Or am I wrong?

@lkishalmi @DevCharly I'm happy with merging--future work can be added in fresh commits.

@DevCharly
On the "minimize" icon discussion: I think the first three screenshots in your comment were OK. Perhaps you can compensate for thinness by making sure the line fills the entire device pixel width available to the icon. Compare for instance with the "minimize" button shown on Windows 10 on the top-right corner of any OS-painted window.

It still looks vertically misaligned next to the X--it should be like an underscore, not a hyphen (so "X _", not "X -").

On the editor tab height discussion: Most screens are widescreen these days, which means vertical space is at a real premium. A Retina MacBook Pro with a 2560x1600 device pixel resolution effectively ends up having only 800 logical pixels available in the vertical direction--30% _less_ than than the laptop I had back in 2004! For this reason I would encourage keeping things tight in the vertical direction, at least in the editor area.

On the tab border discussion: The hover effect is nice, but how does the user know where to aim the mouse when moving it towards a tab? It's not clear where the boundary between one tab and the next is. And in the editor tabs, when there are 3-4 adjacent non-selected tabs open, it will not be immediately visually clear whether the "X" belongs to the tab to the left or the right.

In the screenshots on https://www.formdev.com/flatlaf, the borderless tab works well, because each tab is only a text component. I think the presence of an X button and an icon for each tab makes the borderless approach less feasible. You could add more horizontal space between the tabs, but that would decrease the number of tabs the user can see at once (and I, for one, frequently have 15-20 tabs open). I'd prefer a thin, subtle border between the tabs, and a darker background color for any tabless remaining area to the right.
@lkishalmi +1 on merging

Please don't merge like this. The author information is broken:

> Karl T <DevCharly@users.noreply.github.com>

This is neither a fullname, nor a valid email address. Compared to other Apache projects, we are _very_ relaxed with merge policy. We need to know who was the author, so that if it there is a legal we have solid ground.

If possible I would back-out (e978ba9b235ca1eaeb6f6fddf7dca46c20c337fc) with a revert comment and create a new commit with the proper author information, preferred by @DevCharly personally.

Please don't understand this as an attack - I like the work and value it, so it should also be attributeable.

The "prprts" is surely a problem somewhere else - the source was apparently not consulted for the name, and so a default was used. Why that happened is not clear to me, but it does not have much to do with this patch.

@jlahoda : Could you plz have a look on this.

It goes like this: The method which tries to figure out the host's own IP address is rather elaborate.  If it can't determine anything then it returns the IPv4 loopback address, `127.0.0.1`.

Therefore the test of that method is constructed so that if it returns `127.0.0.1` it is seen a failure in the method. However, along comes Travis and Docker which by design (I guess) doesn't have a network interface.

I would need some time to dig into Travis/Docker to see if the returned `127.0.0.1`  is actually a formally correct response. If so, the test on `myIpAddress` would need to be removed.

I agree with Matthias that changing the Travis environment is the wrong way to go about it for now.

Hi @mglukhikh ,
I think you'd better fitted with the Corporate Contributor License Agreement (CCLA). Please see [1].

If you read point number 8. there:

> It is your responsibility to notify the Foundation when any change
is required to the list of designated employees authorized to submit
Contributions on behalf of the Corporation, or to the Corporation's
Point of Contact with the Foundation.

You'll see that JetBrains has the possibility to modify the list of designated employees authorized to submit Contributions on behalf of JetBrans **at any time**. 

So, for instance, JetBrains could authorize you to submit this contribution and once the contribution is made then remove your authorization to submit any futher contributions.

Would that fit JetBrains' Legal needs?

Thanks,
Antonio


[1]
https://www.apache.org/licenses/contributor-agreements.html

_Every_ class in that module is deprecated since 06/2004. That are 15 years. Lets drop the module and be done with it. We gain nothing from doing an incompatible change (you'd need to document it, update the apichanges.xml) to reinstate these dead classes.

testing live all travis ok

I'm inclined to leave the module as is - someone was there before us - from the `build.xml`:

```
    <!-- ... -->
    <available property="is.jdk9" classname="java.lang.Module"/>
    <import file="../../nbbuild/templates/projectized.xml"/>

    <target name="compile" depends="-copy" unless="is.jdk9">
        <antcall target="projectized-common.compile"/>
    </target>
    <!-- ... -->
```

This translates to: "If the build is run on JDK 9 and newer, just skip this module." The moment we drop build support for JDK8, the module will be gone. We could drop it now, but do we gain anything?

I agree with Matthias - I don't think there's a point in renaming the package. The sole purpose of the module now is compatibility. So we could drop it in some way (like move the binary to some update centre, where anyone who would want to use it could download it).

-I wonder if we are getting to a place where we need a customization for this, so that users can choose if they want to see the names only in some specific cases.

Hi @mglukhikh ,

We could find no CCLA or SGA from JetBrains.

The purpose of IP clearance is to make sure that the owners of any IP explicitly grant Apache the rights needed to modify and redistribute the material.

If JetBrains owns all of the IP, then a CCLA or SGA is usually needed. 
- The SGA is typically used if it is a one-time grant. 
- The CCLA is typically used if there will be continuing grants done by employees (named in the CCLA). 

Where there is a small number of people who wrote all of the material, even if the IP is owned by their employer, then having each of them submit an ICLA (which states in section 4 that they have permission of the IP owner to contribute) will suffice. If there are other IP owners of material here, we need another discussion.

To make forward progress, it might be useful for JetBrains to create a new repository containing only the material that they are granting to Apache.

Please feel free to contact the NetBeans PMC with any questions at private@netbeans.apache.org.

Thanks,
Antonio

@eirikbakke  I'm not the author of the changes, but I appreciate the updates. We have several areas where libraries were not updated over years (javascript the most prominent one) and now we suffer from huge steps that need to be taken. Do you see a problem there?
